text.p: Italian bond futures held at firmer level after touching new record highs in early trading helped by the strength of other European debt markets while support also came from a stronger lira and dollar, dealers said.
The March LIFFE futures contract scored a new record high of 131.75 in morning trading before edging off the highs to last trade up 17 basis points at 131.49 at around 1600 GMT.

Dealers say attention today will focus on the first two Italian cities of Turin and Trieste to report January CPI data later this afternoon at around 1630 GMT ahead of a further nine cities on Tuesday.

Preliminary CPI from 11 sample Italian cities is due today and Tuesday and analysts forecast a month-on-month rise of 0.2 percent and a year-on-year rate of 2.6 percent in January, after 0.1 percent and 2.6 percent rises in December.

Dealers said trading had been moderate with the market reacting to the firmer dollar and a lira touching 31-month highs against the mark, but with the U.S. Treasury market closed today for Martin Luther King day trading activity was subdued.
The BTP market is still largely overbought at the moment and vulnerable to profit taking, but investors see little reason for a big sell-off at the moment, dealers added.

Many investors said that the Bank of Italy is not expected to shift official interest rates until a solution is found to the long-running debate between employers and metalworker and engineering unions over renewing contracts.
